comments.commentBody: I'd add a few thoughts; get to understand what your agreement covers (IE read the book), and while not abusing it, use what it provides.  If your fridge breaks and food spoils, see what's covered.  If your TV doesn't do what it's supposed to and they can't get it to do so (not what you imagine it should do), be persistent.  If your covered item is not repairable (say parts no longer available), they do NEED to replace it and should set you up to come to the store and be taken care of.  Don't lose the booklet.

Desktops are fairly easy and cheap to repair in most cases - and many owners can learn to do the work themselves.  Laptops are much, much harder to repair - and a much better choice for an extended warranty.

Today's appliances are far more efficient and complex - and that leads them to be easier to break down.  Yet in some ways there are improvements, like washers or dryers that pump out diagnpstic codes.  But when they do break down the computer boards are expensive.
I think most students and admin get all As in rationalization.
There turning into corporate and sports institutions.

There's been a lot of knocking on college in general and Ivies in particular.  I can speak for no one else's experience, but I just want to put it out there that Columbia at least is so difficult and requires so much unbelievable time and effort to do well, that there is little time to do anything but study, write papers and go to class. All this talk of a gentleman's agreement that the students will get A's simply because they've always received A's and the professors don't want to have to work hard either, that's nonsense there.  There were weeks on end when I barely left campus.  Hardly left my room except to eat and go to class.  That place is super hard!
I agree with you, Bryan.  The butchering of innocents must stop.  At the same time, the Sunni-Shia conflict makes development of a response more complex and more difficult.

Agreed, Mr. Barrett. I'm amazed Mr. Friedman lists all the conflicts in the Middle East that are now conflagrations without recognition that they were all simply simmering disputes until Mr. Obama put his hand to work or not to work, until he took over the reigns, ignoring the Arab Spring altogether, offering no support to populations yearning to break free of the oppressive regimes of the Middle East. He took on the job and the region went to hell.

The nations that need to unite around a common policy of dealing with, rather than just discussing, ISIS are not just the moderate Arab states.  How about informing the Europeans that times have changed.  The ball is in their court and we will help them as they deal with this problem on the fringes of their neighborhood.  The "progressive' governments of continental Europe can surely lead the way, just as our own "progressives"  point to their examples in health care, education, minimum wages etc.  Let Pierre or Max carry the ball.

Being in favor of destroying ISIS/ISIL is proving to be a hard sell thus far in the US if one judges from the opinions expressed in the NYT during recent weeks as comments insist that these terrorists pose no threat to American interests or to the US. John Kerry wrote that he "demanded" the coalition or alliance of states that you referred to knowing that there are major disagreements, as you have touched upon, among many states in the region and among all 57 Muslim states he may have a hard time convincing or getting a majority to support any such effort by the US.

Within the various relationships among states, clans, tribes and terrorists, there are strange bedfellows. One is that Turkey, who the US considers a solid ally, is a strong Muslim Brotherhood booster. Consider how that will affect their desire to enter the EU? Or their relationship with major Arab countries such as Egypt.

The basic issue which has received scant coverage in the US is the Sunni Vs Shia faction fight which is a major component of the problem as you have mentioned. Since the seventh century it has periodically reoccurred and is part of the fundamental problem in Iraq. Is there a snowballs chance in the desert that Iraq will ever achieve even the remotest semblance of becoming a democracy under such animosity?

The brutal savage murders of Jim Foley and Steven Sotloff are likely the beginning of a protracted campaign by ISIS. They have butchered their prisoners at every opportunity. And will again.

Anetliner Netliner and Larry Lundgren – to repeat what's been said many times before: "We don't have a strategy YET" was part of a response to a reporter asking the Prez "Do you need Congress' approval to go into Syria?" It was the very last phrase of his answer, wherein he explained that he continues to consult with Congress.
Please look it up and read the entire context instead of trying to stir up a storm over nothing.

Sally, My suggested wording would have served the President far better. I am not "stirring up a storm over nothing". The storm was created by the media over the President's remark.  I am merely commenting.

Because Friedman was a cheerleader for the Iraq war - which he minimally refers to in this column, without any apology for its consequences - I don't have much faith in his ability to come up with a cogent analysis. In addition, he's the same guy who said in 2002 that the US, in the previous 20 years, never punished anyone for American deaths, somehow conveniently forgetting that the group who bombed the World Trade Center is spending the next 240 years rotting in prison.

So aside from his poor analyses, his ability to know or remember facts is also in question. Who would trust this guy ever again? I know that even a stopped clock is right twice a day, but that means it's right only about 0.1 percent of the time - and that's about how much I trust Friedman.

Excellent column. I appreciate the detail on the Sunni-Shiite conflict in Iraq that has fueled the rise of ISIS, as well as the discussion of the support for ISIS among wealthy Sunnis from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Qatar. Also useful is the information on the composition of ISIS, as a blending of Sunni radicals and the remains of Saddam Hussein's army.

Friedman's analysis is essential to appreciating the complexities facing the Obama Administration in developing strategy and tactics to subdue ISIS. These complexities require a measured response by the President and his advisors.

At the same time, the President's "We don't have a strategy," comment was stated poorly. A better statement would be: "This is a situation that warrants a measured response, and the U.S. is considering its options."

Kudos to Tom Friedman for this insightful piece.

John, I gather you found a pic somewhere of JO in his later years?

Howie

I'll agree with you there. JOBS are what people need. But there is currently a world-wide, structural lack of jobs. It is not just the US, in fact we are better off than Europe and many other places.

High technology and third-world competition has resulted in a situation where there are simply more workers who need jobs than there are jobs. Nobody on the right OR LEFT has the slightest idea of how to fix this.

Unemployment in Europe is significantly higher than here, excepting only Germany. But what we have, that Europe lacks, is a vast underclass of poor minorities in nearly every large city. They continue to present an intransigent problem for EVERY social program, which no matter how well funded, is quickly overwhelmed.

To extend (say) Swedish style benefits to the 30% of Americans who live in inner city ghettos or poor rural areas, would be an utter disaster and entirely unsustainable. Worst of all, it would not help. These areas already have massive generational welfare, and people who have literally no concept of working for a living. All they care about is "their benefits" -- how to get the most of them, how to stay on them (even when you cheat egregiously).

Worst of all: most of the benefits we try and direct to children, end up going to adults. Give money to the schools -- it goes into the lux benefits for public union teachers. Give money for food stamps -- the recipients sell them for cash, and spend the cash on tomfoolery.

While I agree wholeheartedly with some of what you propose, such as an increase in the minimum wage or earned income tax credit, I'm afraid that you are asking for an expensive, impractical tangle of programs that will do little to address the problems of the poor and their children.

Jobs are what lift people out of poverty, and education, which allows people to get better jobs. Our current policy of globalization and illegal immigration has put serious downward pressure on wages, particularly those of the poor, and the availability of jobs, and fiscal conservatism, by retarding the growth of the economy, has made the situation even worse.

Ah yes.  When I was a kid (late 60s/early 70s) I would tell people that my mother was a doctor and they would say "oh, you mean a nurse."  And then I'd have to explain that no, my mother was a lady doctor --- as opposed to a normal doctor, I guess.
The recklessness behind ISIS reminds a lot people of 9/11 though

Simon, you are correct about the Saudis, Qataris and other Gulf States. However, ISIS also benefitted from the polciies of President Obama and Hillary Clinton and of Turkey's hardline Islamist PResident, Erdogan. Erdogan is largely resposbile for the mess in the Middle east right now and he has openly supported calls for a Caliphate. While the SAudis support Wahhabism, they are sensible and have tried to control these forces over decades. Qatar and Turkeuy with the the current US adminstration tried to overthrown Assad and this is the result.

ISIS IS created from Free Syrian Army. And what is so special about the Free Syrian army? They are sunni extremists that were fighting against the Alawites (Assad's tribe). Assad has been fighting so hard, because he anticipated the same fate as the Yazidis if he didn't. If President Assad hadn't received the support of Putin, ISIS(yeah, free syrian army!), would have massacred Alawaites and the arab invaders would have destroyed another ancient people of hte Middle East!
Charlie, Iraqi government is still a baby, we have to give them time.  Or we are only giving ourselves tough time, and maybe even another 9/11 is waving its hands at us
Kurds, Turkemeni and Turks are all different people.......

It wasn't just that. We all recoil with horror at what's happenign to the Yazidis and other minorities in IRaq right now. the Kurds were being massacred before hte American Invasion. Remeber Saddam Hussein's gas attacks against the kurds?
Mike, I completely agree with you, but Iraq doesn't need a hero, as heros are all about self glamour, they need a big man that can take the people to the promised land

The coda in the last three paragraphs is unbearably sad. I hope the US, notwithstanding its legitimate reservations in becoming embroiled yet again in Iraq, can find a way to destroy these ISIS fanatics. Not contain or push back. Destroy.
This is what a new country do though, alot of struggles, fightings, and dyings, once they have a solid leader, things will turn around

Looking for allies to engage Isis is the cowards way. The President, as Commander in Chief should be asking for thousands of volunteers to attack ISIS where ever  it has troops, without regard for the artificial borders drawn up by fiat following WW I. As Commander in Chief the President has the Constitutional authority to send in the troops as did Franklin Roosevelt and then tell Congress to pay for their safe return, after ISIS is destroyed. Drone strikes should continue non stop as well! ISIS killing  more hostages will be unfortunate collateral damage, but that's the price for elimination of the terror threat.
I agree with you, Bryan.  The butchering of innocents must stop.  At the same time, the Sunni-Shia conflict makes development of a response more complex and more difficult.

Vietnam all over again. When will we learn.
REH
All hail the Kurdish Air Force.

I'd like to see pictures of the thousands of Russian troops Senator Robert Menendez claims are present. Maxwell Smart: "would you believe a sqaud of retired security guards?. No? Well, then would you believe an angry boyscout with a pea shooter?" I'm all for sending the Senator to war. He seems to be drooling for blood.
